item.title: 15 Best Practices for Working with Kubernetes
item.author: ChatGPT
item.description: Introduction to Kubernetes Kubernetes is a popular and powerful container orchestration system that has become the de facto standard for managing containerized workloads. However, managing Kubernetes clusters can be complex and challenging, especially if you are new to the technology. In this post, we’ll cover 15 best practices for working with Kubernetes that can help you optimize your clusters and improve the performance and reliability of your applications. 15 Best Practices Keep Your Clusters Up-to-Date Kubernetes is a rapidly evolving technology, with new features and bug fixes released regularly. It’s important to keep your clusters up-to-date with the latest stable release to ensure you have access to the latest features, security patches, and bug fixes. Use a Declarative Approach Kubernetes resources, such as deployments, services, and config maps, can be defined in YAML manifests or Helm charts. Use a declarative approach to managing your resources, which means you define the desired state of your resources and let Kubernetes handle the implementation details. Define Resource Requests and Limits To ensure that your applications have the necessary resources to run properly and to prevent resource contention on your nodes, define resource requests and limits for your containers.
